Except for some classical music references (mainly to Richard Wagner), Schulze next to never went for other composers' works.

name: Arden & Maisie

The Craigs worked for six years at the former "Piccadilly Corner" in The Olympic Hotel (nowadays Fairmont Hotel), a historic hotel in downtown Seattle, where they performed everything from humorous English pub music to Broadway show tunes. They also worked for about seven years at the SeaTac Holiday Inn near the airport of Seattle. They recorded some self-released album. Arden Craig died on June 1, 1990.

name: Glad

Over time, the band's sound evolved toward jazz-pop and all of its releases featured at least one a cappella performance.  In 1988, the group issued an all a cappella album that proved to be very popular.  Subsequently, the group began alternating between a cappella and band albums and now usually performs a cappella Christian music.

name: Martin Lass

In adulthood, Lass subsequently returned to the United States where he live some 10 years, although he is once again based in Australia. Lass is a violinist who first gained notice playing classical music, but he has had crossover success playing popular and gypsy music. Lass is also a composer. In addition to music, Lass has made a name for himself as a professional astrologer, practicing  since the late-1980s. Lass has written on astrological subjects and gives presentations to astrological societies.

He began his stage career in Vienna before moving to Germany where he had his breakthrough, first on the stage, then in film in Berlin in the late 1920s and early 1930s. He played The Governor (Nakamura) in the 1929 Berlin production of the Brecht/Weill musical "Happy End". Lorre caused an international sensation in the German film " (1931) in which he portrayed a serial killer who preys on little girls.

Also arrangements were written for recordings by Rob McConnell, Pepper Adams, Hank Jones, Bill Perkins, Benny Carter, Buddy DeFranco, Toots Thielemans, Clark Terry, Lee Konitz, Lew Tabackin, Claudio Roditi, Andy Martin and dozens more.

The band is perhaps most known for notorious inebriation, narcotics, rehab and depressions. Gained cult status during their active years 1982-1994 and was included in Rockheim Hall of Fame in 2011. Joachim Nielsen went on to release two solo albums after the band ended, and died of a heroin overdose in October 2000.

name: Jokke
comments: Songwriter, composer, guitarist, pianist, vocalist. Was the primary force behind Jokke & Valentinerne, one of the "four great" rock bands in Norway, and later Jokke med Tourettes. Brother of cartoonist Christopher Nielsen and son of the artist John David Nielsen. Died of a heroin overdose, 36 years old.

name: Kaizers Orchestra
comments: Kaizers Orchestra was a Norwegian alternative rock group that formed on 1st of January 2000. They are notable for being among the first non-black metal Norwegian bands or artists singing in their native language to become popular beyond Scandinavia. To other Norwegians, the band is instantly recognizable both because of their unique, unpredictable style, and because of vocalist Ottesen's distinctive Jæren dialect, shared by four of the other band members. In 2012, the group announced that following a 2013 "Farewell Tour", they would take a long break. Their final concert was held on September 14th 2013 at DNB Arena in Stavanger.

He built the first double-neck steel guitar and later became the manufacturer of the "Bradway Custom Built Steel Guitar." He also built and played a triple neck guitar. In the early 1940s he formed a trio, the "Hawaiianaires," which performed in the Atlantic City area. In 1955 he and his wife, Jean, began full-time evangelic work with a ministry of music and testimony..

name: El Vate

After travelling through some two dozen countries, El Vate settled in the New York City area, where he was often heard playing his music -- a fusion of Andean music and jazz -- in Times Square.  In addition, he played with a number of famous artists, and recorded with Frank Sinatra and Paul Simon.  He also was hired by Warner Brothers to do session work on movie soundtracks.

The band members are all officially 23 years old and never age.

name: Knutsen & Ludvigsen

They had several #1 hits, including "Grevling i taket", "Hallo! Hallo!" and "Dum og deilig". Since the late 90's, they have enjoyed a cult status among young Norwegians, performing a series of reunion concerts.

name: Gustav Lorentzen

He went solo in 1986, winning four Spellemann (Norwegian Grammy) awards and one nomination for his 5 albums. From 1997 until his death, Lorentzen collaborated with the psychologist Magne Raundalen, creating a therapeutic program for traumatized children, mainly victims of wars. He was also a UNICEF Ambassador since 1993. On 21 April 2010, Lorentzen collapsed during an orienteering competition outside of Bergen and went into cardiac arrest. He was pronounced dead a few minutes later.

name: Winston Sela

name: Hans-Otto Borgmann

A melody he had composed for a documentary on Svalbard island was taken up by Hitler Youth leader Baldur von Schirach who wrote new lyrics as "Unsre Fahne flattert uns voran", thus becoming one of the Hitler Youth's anthems. In 1938 he composed a "Großdeutsche Hymne" for Von Schirach, which coincided with the Anschluss of Austria.

In 1955 she was a vocalist with Lionel Hampton. She was a member of the female vocal group, The Charmers. Patty Anne was also a songwriter.

name: Edmund Eysler
comments: Austrian composer born in Vienna in a merchant family. He was supposed to enter the engineering profession, but he went to the Vienna Conservatory, where he studied composition and was educated as a piano teacher and Kapellmeister. After World War I Eysler published a very successful operetta "Die gold’ne Meisterin" (The Golden Mistress). Due to Eysler's Jewish background his works were banned by the Nazis in the 1930s and Adolf Hitler discovered, that his favourite operetta - Die gold'ne Meisterin - was the work of a Jew. Instead of fleeing he found shelter with relatives and friends in Vienna.

comments: Woody Allen's career in show business started in the 1950s as a comedy writer.  In the early 1960s, Allen started doing stand-up comedy performing monologues instead of traditional jokes.  As a stand-up comic, Allen has released several records. Later in the 1960s, he started directing and acting in films as well as screenwriting.  He is also a playwright and has appeared as a stage actor.  Allen is best known for his films.  He has been nominated for multiple Academy Awards, and won three Academy Awards for Best Original Screenplay and one for Best Director. Allen also plays New Orleans-style jazz clarinet and has had a regular gig playing with his band at the Carlyle Hotel in New York City for years.  He has also released several records on which he is credited as leader or co-leader.

comments: Duo made up of Eva Weel Skram and her husband Thomas Stenersen, with Eva on main vocals.

name: Martin Sjølie
comments: Songwriter and music producer

name: Thomas Stenersen
comments: Guitarist and songwriter.

name: Simon Walker
comments: Songwriter

name: Børge Fjordheim
comments: Singer-songwriter and drummer

name: Ena Baga
comments: Resident organist of the Tower Ballroom, Blackpool during World War 2.

name: Calle Ask
comments: Producer and songwriter

name: Melissa Swift-Sawyer
comments: Musical actor and singer from Westminster, Colorado

name: Lowtide
comments: Dream pop / shoegaze quartet from Melbourne.

name: Suzanne Sumbundu
comments: Singer

name: Hurra Torpedo
comments: Hurra Torpedo is a band who play songs using kitchen appliances. They were formed in the early nineties, are part of the artistic collective Duplex Records , and all members of the band also play in a variety of other bands in Norway, mostly associated with Duplex.

name: Lisa Dames
comments: Country music singer

name: Origene
comments: Trance group composed of producers Ben Grayson and Brian Canham, and vocalist Matilda White.

name: Peter Roberts
comments: Legendary soprano cornet player in brass bands.   He grew up and continues to live in Grimethorpe, Yorkshire, England, where he worked for 27 years in the Grimethorpe Colliery.  During his 40 years of active playing - he retired in 2007 - Roberts playing on soprano cornet won six British Opens, two Masters, three Europeans, one National, two Overall British Solo Championships, five British Soprano Soloist titles, and an International Solo Championship.

name: Yorkshire Building Society Band
comments: One of England's long-running brass bands.  It was formed in 1855 as the Saltaire Band, before becoming the Hammonds Sauce Works Band (until the Hammonds Sauce Company dropped its sponsorship), the Yorkshire Building Society Band (when the Yorkshire Building Society became its sponsor), in 2004 when this sponsorship ended, it became the YBS Band and since 2007 it has been the Hammonds Saltaire Band.  It has won many prizes, including eight European Brass Band Championships as the Yorkshire Building Society Band.

name: David King [AU]
comments: Cornet and trumpet player, starting in his youth in Australia.  After receiving a BA from Avondale, NSW, he moved to Melbourne, and was appointed the principal cornet for the Hawthorn City Band in 1979.  In 1981, King became the Australian Cornet Champion and was accepted a scholarship at Salford College in Manchester, England.  He then began conducting brass bands, and has represented England as conductor in 11 European Brass Band Championships.  His bands won ten times - twice with the Black Dyke Mills Band and eight times with the Yorkshire Building Society Band .  He has also directed winning brass bands in Norway and Australia.  He taught in the music department of Salford for many years.

name: Pachanga
comments: Reggaeton duo originally consisting of Brazilian Jay Del Alma and Spaniard Rico Caliente. Caliente left in 2011 and was only replaced in 2015 by Chilenian MC Sesman.

name: Ralph Young
comments: Singer, whose career spanned the big-band era, Broadway and television, and actor. Best known as the partner of Tony Sandler in the singing duo of Sandler and Young.

name: Bootsy Spankins, P.I.
comments: Pop singer-songwriter based in Philadelphia

name: Tony Sandler
comments: Singer, best known as the partner of Ralph Young in the singing duo of Sandler and Young

name: Cathy Clasper-Torch
comments: Singer and multi-instrumentalist (violin/fiddle, piano, erhu, cello) based in Rhode Island. Clasper-Torch plays multiple styles, including world-folk, rock, jazz, and classical.

name: Rachel Panitch
comments: Boston-based violinist, improviser, composer, and teaching artist. Panitch performs classical music with the Cardamom Quartet, is a dance fiddler with French Roast, and weaves stories with Thread Ensemble (an improvisatory trio of violins, voices and vibraphone) and with Grammy award-winner Bill Harley.

name: Peters Drury Trio
comments: From Whitehorse, Yukon, Canada, the Peters Drury Trio was Caroline Drury, vocals, Jesse Peters, piano and vocals, and Graeme Peters on drums.  They were a vocal jazz trio together for eight years, breaking up in 2005 or 2006.

name: BenjaSoul
comments: R&B/hip-hop project of Benjamin Mertz, a gospel choir director, jazz pianist, flutist, and music educator living in California's East Bay.

name: Ezra Collective
comments: London-based ensemble with influences ranging from afro-beat, reggae, jazz and hip-hop

name: Pierre DuMont
comments: Smooth jazz/easy listening saxophonist from Quebec, who also occasionally sings.

name: Roger Lecussant
aliases: Roger Lecussant and His Club Lido Orchestra
comments: Composer and bandleader in the 1950s and 1960s

name: Guylaine Guy
comments: Singer and painter from Montreal in Quebec. In 1954 Charles Trenet discovered Guylaine in Montreal and began writing songs for her. She made her French debut at the Olympia with Charles Trenet and Louis Armstrong and settled permanently in Paris in 1956. She recorded several Trenet songs and performed at the Bobino Theater.

name: Passerine
comments: Folk and Americana band founded in Sarasota, Florida in 2009.

name: Michel Frenc
comments: Singer who was active in the 1950s and 1960s and was called by the French press "le seul chanteur qui ne veut pas devenir une vedette" (the only singer, who does not want to become a star). He gave up singing and now lives in a small town in Normandy.

name: Lucien Adès
comments: Record producer born in Constantine in Algeria. He was the representative of the Walt Disney company in France.

name: Louise Homer
comments: Popular operatic singer from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. She was a leading contra-alto with the Metropolitan Opera in New York for two decades.

name: Gérard Brumières
comments: Singer and songwriter

name: Robert Piquet
comments: Singer of light classical music in the 1950s and 1960s. In 1970 he sang in a vocal quartet called  "Les Poivre et Sel", whic was created by the singer-comedian Dominique Tirmont with Francis Linel and Georges Blaness.

name: Nico D
comments: Rapper and reggae artist. Holter have played with OnkelP , Admiral P og Jah Mason and is a part of the reggea group Jah Ark Manifest. As the first Scandinavian, Nico D reached the top of the singel list in Jamaica (together with Jah Mason) with "Ruff Times" in 2009. Together with Admiral P he won Song of the Year at Spellemannsprisen (Norwegian Grammy) in 2014 for the song Engel .

name: Haviland Stillwell
comments: Broadway actress and singer

name: Yngvar Numme
comments: Musician, revue writer and artist, director and entertainer. Most known as member and vocalist in the revue group Dizzy Tunes.

name: Eef Barzelay
comments: Singer/songwriter based in Nashville, TN.

name: The Monroes
comments: Pop and ska duo, consisting of singer Lage Fosheim and guitarist Eivind Rølles. They recorded four successful studio albums between 1983 and 1993, before disbanding. Initially strongly influenced by English ska band Madness, their debut single "Sunday People" reached number one on the Norwegian charts in 1983. Their music rapidly evolved into a more laidback, melodious pop style, and they reached number one again with "Cheerio" in 1985, also charting in the U.S. Their 1985 album "Face Another Day" is regularly featured on critics' lists of Norway's best pop/rock albums ever.

name: Eivind Rølles
comments: Vocalist, drummer, keyboardist, songwriter and record producer. Member of the successful pop duo The Monroes in the 1980's with Lage Fosheim. Later worked as A&R and marketing manager in BMG and EMI. Died from cancer.

name: Lage Fosheim
comments: Musician and record promoter, most known as member of the duo The Monroes, regarded as one of the biggest Norwegian pop band in the 1980s.

name: Tracee Meyn
comments: American singer, artist, composer and song teacher, born and raised in Los Angeles, California.

name: Manto Negro
comments: Hard rock band

name: Folk & Røvere
comments: Trip hop-band lead by Ulf «Ulph» Nygaard. Established in 1994 in Oslo. Most of their songs are sung in Norwegian.

name: Lorraine Serabian
comments: Broadway actress.

name: Tore Johansen
comments: Trumpet player from Bodø.

name: Stella Mwangi
comments: Born in Nairobi in Kenya. Most famous in Norway for her victory in the Norwegian entry in Eurovision Song Contest 2011.

name: Alpha Cat
comments: Mostly female indie rock band.

name: Kjell Halbing
comments: Writer, most know under the pseudonym Louis Masterson. He wrote the book series about the western hero Morgan Kane, 83 books in all.

name: Amanda MacKinnon
comments: Alias "Manda Rin".

name: Polecat Boogie Revival
comments: Southern rock band from Tennessee.

name: Manfred Durban
comments: Drummer and songwriter

name: Olaf Malolepski
comments: Singer and songwriter born in Magdeburg

name: Kastelruther Spatzen
comments: Musical group from South Tyrol, northern Italy, who have won many honours and awards for their schlager in folk music style. The first word in the name of the group refers to their home town of Kastelruth.

name: Peter Cooper
comments: Country music singer-songwriter bashed in Nashville.  He has worked as a producer or session musician for many country-oriented artists, including, but not limited to,  Todd Snider,  Tom T. Hall, Bobby Bare, Rodney Crowell, Nanci Griffith and Patty Griffin. Cooper is also a music writer and a senior lecturer in country music at Vanderbilt University’s Blair School of Music.

name: Vido Musso
comments: Italian born jazz tenor saxophonist, clarinetist and bandleader

name: Trio Raisner
comments: Harmonica players, who also sang, danced and made gags on stage. They toured in France, Germany, and Italy.

name: Terry Baxter
aliases: Terry Baxter / His Orchestra and Chorus
Terry Baxter His Orchestra and Chorus
Terry Baxter - His Orchestra and Chorus
The Terry Baxter Orchestra and Chorus

name: De Musikalske Dvergene
comments: Rock group from Bergen, established in 1980.

name: Gino del Vescovo
comments: Classical mandolin player

name: Ivy Willis
comments: Rhythm and blues singer, who was active as a recording artist at the second part of the 1940s.

name: Andy Owens
comments: Bluegrass multi-instrumentalist best known for mandolin.  He has performed in many countries to spread blue grass music.  Owens is also a songwriter and teaches students to play several instruments associated with bluegrass music.

name: Manuel Clavero
comments: Author, lyricist and publisher

name: Helge Grønhaug
comments: Guitarist, singer, translator and lyricist.

name: Los Tiburones
comments: Rock quartet from Barcelona consisting of José Alcaraz (drums), Guillermo Alcaraz (bass), Enric Maier (guitar) and Enrique Baig (guitar).

name: Finn Eriksen
comments: Trumpet player. Besides Arve Tellefsen and Ole Edvard Antonsen the best selling Norwegian (instrumental music) in Norway. Recorded on over 1000 releases.

name: Kjell Karlsen
comments: Pianist, jazz musician, composer and bandleader born in Sarpsborg

name: Los Top-Son
comments: Rock quartet from Valencia founded by Pascual Olivas and Vicente Castelló after Los Milos broke up.

name: Frank O. Anthun
comments: Author and translator

name: Harry Mortimer
aliases: Harry Mortimer and His All-Star Brass
comments: Composer and conductor who specialised in brass band music. He is regarded as the world's best ever cornet player. Some of his arrangements for brass band were credited under his alias H.R. Moreton.

name: Blue Murder [GB2]
comments: Folk music supergroup approaching the material a cappella as a folk chorus.  Much more of a performing group than a recording group.

name: Winifred Horan
comments: Fiddler born of Irish parents in New York City, she plays Celtic and Irish folk music.

name: Julie Gregg
comments: Television, film and stage actress and singer.

name: Shane Rimmer
comments: Canadian (Toronto) born actor, voice actor, and singer, living in the UK since the late 1950s. Best known for providing the voice of Scott Tracy in the British television series Thunderbirds.

name: Rosemary Harris
comments: Actress who had considerable success on Broadway.

name: Gerald Trimble
comments: Trimble plays a variety of old, rarely seen instruments in modern times, and is particularly renowned for the viola da gamba, a fretted, bowed instrument that somewhat resembles a cello, but has five to seven strings.  It was most popular in Renaissance and Baroque Europe.  In addition to interpreting the historical music of the instrument, he plays jazz, rock and world music.  Trimble also sings.

name: Love, Peace & Happiness
comments: Vocal Trio: Ann Bogan, Leslie Wilson & Melvin Wilson.

name: Norman Baillie-Stewart
comments: British army  and an active sympathizer of Nazi Germany. He took part in German-produced propaganda broadcasts and is known as one of the men associated with the nickname "Lord Haw-Haw". He translated the lyrics of "Lili Marleen" into English as sung by Lale Andersen, which was a form of propaganda towards Allied soldiers, but then taken up by the Allies themselves.

name: Mike Watson
aliases: Little Mike and The Sweet Soul Music Band
comments: Sheffield born bass guitarist who has worked primarily in Sweden

name: Annick Bouquet
comments: Actress and pop singer, active as a recording artist in the first half of the 1960s

name: Linda Ciofalo
comments: NYC born jazz vocalist

name: Catherine Chisholm Cushing
comments: Lyricist, composer and author. She wrote the Broadway librettos for a variety of shows. Her chief collaborations were with Rudolf Friml and Hugo Felix.

name: Louis Ducreux
comments: Actor, screenwriter and composer born in Marseille.

name: Harold Purcell
comments: Lyricist

name: Jan Rosol
comments: Singer, born in Le Havre in 1921, who escaped to England from occupied France in 1943 and joined the Free French Forces. Detailed to tour England as a singer he decided to dedicate himself to French folk music. But he was probably best known as a broadcaster, singing and playing regularly for the Home, Light and Third programme networks of the BBC and from 1948 performed every week in various programmes for schools. Little is known of Jan Rosol from the mid-1960s onwards.

name: Teddy Johnson [GB]
comments: Teddy Johnson and his wife Pearl Carr were an English husband-and-wife team of entertainers popular during the 1950s and early 1960s. Johnson had led his own teenage band, was a professional drummer and a recording artist for Columbia in the early 1950s.

name: Felix King
aliases: Felix King, His Piano and His Orchestra
Felix King, His Piano and Orchestra
comments: Pianist and bandleader. In 1932 he formed a band to play at the Gargoyle Club in London, but was soon to spend much of his time as pianist in leading dance bands in London, writing music for films and playing in them.

name: The Renaults
comments: Instrumental band in the 1960s

name: Byron Berline
comments: Fiddler active in many different musical genres. He is a 3-time National Fiddle Champion, has played with several famous bluegrass and country bands and is a popular session musician.

name: Thelma Houston
comments: Singer-songwriter, actress

comments: R&B/nu soul singer-songwriter and producer.

comments: Alternative country and bluegrass band

comments: Electro multi-instrumentalist and vocalist.

comments: Psychedelic group with a folk edge from Chicago.

name: Terry Callier
comments: Jazz, soul and folk guitarist and singer-songwriter

name: Brainbox
comments: Progressive rock band formed in 1969.

name: "D" Train
comments: R&B duo

name: Eumir Deodato
comments: Pop Jazz pianist, composer, record producer and arranger.

name: J.T. Taylor
comments: Soul singer

name: Peter Andre
comments: Singer, songwriter, and television personality. Andre was born in the UK and moved back there.

name: Affinity [GB]
comments: Progressive rock/jazz-rock band active from mid-1968 until early-1972.

name: The New World Singers
comments: The New World Singers were a 1960s folk revival group. Members included Happy Traum, Gil Turner, Bob Cohen and Deloris Dixon

name: Kevin Coyne
aliases: Kevin Coyne and the Paradise Band
comments: Singer, songwriter, guitarist, painter, poet and writer, born in Derby, England

name: Bis [GB]
comments: Scottish indie pop band

name: Lolita No. 18

name: Boris the Sprinkler ‎
comments: Punk rock band from Green Bay, Wisconsin, known for their flamboyant satirical style with a supplemental dash of bizarre imagery.

name: Dieter Moebius
comments: Experimental/ambient keyboard player, who with Hans-Joachim Roedelius and Michael Rother formed Harmonia. Moebius and Roedelius were also active as Cluster/Kluster/Qluster for a number of years.

name: Hans-Joachim Roedelius
comments: Spearheading electronic music artist and composer collaborating in many projects. Also a writer and experimental movies creator.

name: The Shanes [SE]
comments: Pop / rock quintet consisting of Lennart Grahn, Tommy Wåhlberg (guitar, vocals), Kit Sundqvist, Svante Elfgren (bass) and Tor-Erik Rautio (drums).

name: Troppi Trippi Inc.
comments: Electro pop act

name: Wonderlick
comments: Indie rock band based in Los Angeles

name: Zoot Woman
comments: Electronic british band.

name: Zig-Zag
comments: Dance troupe from the Granada TV pop show called "45", which was broadcast in 1974 and 1975.

name: Jem Finer
comments: Multi-instrumentalist

name: Descendents
comments: Punk rock band formed in Manhattan Beach, California.

name: Dennis Matkosky
comments: Songwriter and producer

name: Vinnie Dombroski
comments: Rock music singer-songwriter, producer and musician

name: Joey Mazzola
comments: Rock music songwriter and guitarist

name: Jimmy Paluzzi
comments: Rock music singer-songwriter and drummer

name: Mike Cross [US2]
comments: Rock music guitarist and songwriter

name: Tim Cross [US]
comments: Rock music bassist

name: Evergreen Terrace
comments: Metalcore band from Jacksonville, Florida

name: Dee Carstensen
comments: Harpist, pianist, singer and songwriter

name: The Cruel Sea
comments: Indie rock band from Sydney, New South Wales

name: Craig Erickson
comments: Mainly a Blues Rock guitarst.

name: Roy Mette
comments: Guitarist & singer

name: Pinguin Moschner
comments: Tuba Player

name: Paolo Fresu
comments: Jazz trumpet and flugelhorn player, arranger and composer.

name: Keith Green
comments: Influential Christian singer-songwriter and pianist, who recorded three singles produced by Gary Usher as a youngster.

name: Amon Tobin
personal_name: Amon Adonai Santos de Araujo Tobin

name: Scotty Anderson
comments: Guitarist based in Cincinnati, Ohio

name: DJ Lethal
comments: Latvian-born beatboxer, turntablist and producer.

name: Ludwig Schmidseder
comments: Composer, pianist and actor born  in Passau

name: Sten Axelson
aliases: Sten Axelsons Orkester med sång av “Vagabonds”
comments: Composer, singer, pianist and bandleader born in Tidan in Västra Götaland County.

name: Leon Liljeqvist
comments: Composer, lyricist, singer, yodeller and trumpeter born in Skövde.

name: Leonard Cooke
comments: Lyricist active in the 1910s

name: Lilian Ray
comments: Composer

name: Oscar Ralf
comments: Opera singer - tenor - and translator of opera- and operetta lyrics born in Malmö.

name: Hans Byttner
comments: Drummer and xylophonist , who led his own band by the early 1940s. Also he recorded a total of three solo sides through his career.

name: Jessie Broughton
comments: English contralto and actress. She made her stage debut at the Apollo Theatre in London in 1903 and soon appeared in the West End. In 1910 she married and with her husband she performed in London. She toured Britain and abroad in variety and music hall and made recordings until the 1930s.

name: Robin Proper-Sheppard
comments: US born singer and songwriter based in Brussels

name: Boemerang
comments: Entertainment band from the town of Mill in the province of Brabant.

name: Edward Simoni
comments: German-Polish panflutist born  in Beuthen, Poland.

name: Rita Hunter
comments: British operatic dramatic soprano born in Wallasey, Merseyside. She will be best remembered as one of the major Wagnerian sopranos of the later 20th century, especially for her performances as all three of the Brünnhildes in "Der Ring des Nibelungen". In 1981 she moved to Sydney and joined the Australian Opera.

name: Arthur A. Penn
comments: Composer and arranger born in London (UK), and died in New London, Connecticut (USA).

name: Prinzo & Betzi Winterstein
comments: Gypsy jazz guitarists of the Sinto people -- a Romani people of central Europe.

name: Three Fingered Jack
comments: From Corvallis, Oregon, the band takes its name from a mountain of the same name in the Cascades of western Oregon.  The band plays English folk, Celtic and world music.

name: Harry Frankel
comments: Minstrel performer, vaudevillian and popular personality during the early days of radio. He was best known as "Singin' Sam, the Barbasol Man" for his long association with that company.

name: Nick Nichols
comments: Blues singer

name: Annie Fortescue Harrison
comments: English composer of songs and piano pieces. In 1877 she married and became known as Lady Arthur Hill. She is best known for her 1877 song 'In The Gloaming'.

name: Beth Challis
comments: Contralto singer

name: Meta Orred
comments: Scottish author and poet. She lived most of her life in England, where she produced her literature and poetry. The lyrics for the popular song "In the Gloaming" with music by Annie Fortescue Harrison come from "Poems" (1874).

name: Teddy James
comments: Boy soprano who was advertised as a "boy chorister". In 1930 he was soloist at St Marie's Church in Sheffield.

name: Brent Carver
comments: Actor best known for his performances on Broadway in Parade as Leo Frank and Kiss of the Spider Woman as Molina, for which he won the Tony Award for Best Leading Actor in a Musical in 1993.

name: Jack Gilford
comments: Broadway, film and television actor

name: Jason Alexander
comments: Actor, comedian, director, producer, singer, and writer, from Newark, New Jersey. He is perhaps best known for playing the role of "George Costanza" on the television show, Seinfeld in the 1990s.

name: David Garrison
comments: Stage actor from Long Branch, New Jersey

name: Charlene Soraia
comments: Alternative folk singer and songwriter based in London.

name: Amanda Poulson
comments: Musical theatre and cabaret performer.

name: Mark Schoenfeld
comments: Musical theatre songwriter.

name: Barri McPherson
comments: Musical theatre songwriter.

name: Eden Espinosa
comments: Singer and stage actress who is best known for her performances as Elphaba for the Broadway, Los Angeles, and San Francisco productions of the musical Wicked.

name: Derek Sarjeant and Hazel King
comments: One of the early English folk revival groups, the duo performed together for some 35 years.  The pair married and they performed as Derek and Hazel Sarjeant until Hazel's death from a rare cancer in 2003.

name: John Goodluck
comments: Traditional singer; Goodluck also plays guitar, the whistle and melodeon.

name: Eli Hudson
comments: Flute player (flautist) and conductor, who enjoyed great success as an orchestral flute player, but had a parallel career as a music hall artist, often appearing in a trio with his singer wife Eleanor Jones - stage name Olga - and Eli’s sister, Winifred, who called herself Elgar (after their friend, the composer Edward Elgar).

name: Cecil Sharp Centenary Collective
comments: Folk group.

name: Heinrich Werner
comments: German composer, who is said to have written 84 compositions, mostly songs, including a setting of Goethe's poem "Heidenröslein". It was first publicly performed in 1829 - under his direction - and bore as title the first line, "Sah ein Knab' ein Röslein stehn" (A boy saw a little rose standing).

name: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
comments: Writer and statesman

name: The Beat Brothers [DE]
comments: Beat group from the 1960s from the Hamburg scene. 'The Beat Brothers' was a generic name of several backing bands of Tony Sheridan. As such they did not have a fixed lineup of musicians. One of many groups of musicians who ran under this name were the early Beatles (with Pete Best on drums) during their stint in Hamburg, Germany.

name: Michael Maybrick
comments: English composer and singer best known - under his pseudonym Stephen Adams - as the composer of "The Holy City," one of the most popular religious songs in English.

name: Charles Leggett
aliases: Cornet Solo by Sergeant Leggett, Soloist of H.M. Scots Guards Band with Orchestra
comments: Brighton-born cornetist, who became known as "The World's Finest Cornet Soloist" and who was the favorite cornet soloist of King Edward VII. He joined the Scots Guards Regimental Band a year after first hearing them at the Hove Exhibition in 1890 rising to become Band-Sergeant of the Scots Guards and Principal Professor of Cornet at Kneller Hall of the Royal Military School of Music.

name: Jean-Baptiste Faure
comments: Operatic baritone and art collector, who also composed a number of classical songs.

name: Nan Knighton
comments: Poet, playwright and lyricist

name: Robert Evans
comments: Tenor in the 1910s

name: John Adams [GB1]
comments: Tenor

name: Lew White
comments: Theatre organist, who played on the Stanley Theatre circuit and appeared as guest organist in theatres throughout the country. Throughout his career he taught organ and established The Lew White Institute for Organ for theatre organists. Lew White recorded for Brunswick, Victor and Lang-Worth radio transcriptions.

name: Alice Guszalewicz
comments: Dramatic soprano born in Budapest and in 1896 at the age of 17 married opera singer Eugen Guszalewicz. She made her debut in 1903 at the Theater of Bern in Switzerland. In 1905 she sang at the Cologne Opera as the Queen of Sheba in "La reine de Saba" by Gounod and as Isolde in Wagner's masterpiece. Shortly after her role in "Tristan und Isolde" she was offered a six-year contract to sing in Cologne.

name: Walter Eiger
comments: Pianist, composer, arranger and bandleader born in Łódź in Poland, but active in France

name: W.D. McFarland
comments: Singer from Washington, a "vigorous tenor with an unusual range".

name: Eugene Paul
comments: Reggae singer

name: Fate Marable
comments: Jazz pianist and bandleader

name: Die Kavalier
comments: Masked guitarist.

name: Gilbert Gibson
comments: Songwriter.

name: Copper Family
comments: Family of unaccompanied traditional singers.  Their art and craft has been passed down through many generations.  The family's roots in the village of Rottingdean go back to the 16th century.  The family has proven to be invaluable to the preservation of traditional English folk music because of the number of songs they knew.

name: Bob Copper
comments: Traditional unaccompanied folksinger born in Rottingdean, England. Although the Copper Family had been singers for generations before Bob, Bob became the patriarch of the singing family during the period they began recording commercially.

name: Janet Dacal
comments: Cuban-American actress, singer, and performer in musical theatre born in Los Angeles, California

name: Darren Ritchie
comments: Actor and singer, originally from Florida.

name: Jeff Bowen
comments: Composer, lyricist and actor, originally from Baltimore, Maryland.

name: Heidi Blickenstaff
aliases: Heidi Blickenstaff & the Original Broadway Cast
comments: Actress based in New York City

name: Charlie Wills
comments: Unaccompanied traditional folksinger from Dorset.

name: Bernard Wrigley
comments: Folksinger, musician (mainly guitar and concertina), actor, comedian and storyteller sometimes called the "Bolton bullfrog", with Bolton, referring to his place of birth.

name: Walter Pardon
comments: Traditional unaccompanied folksinger and carpenter from Norfolk who was unknown outside his family as a singer until the age of 59.  Pardon also played melodeon.

name: Bernhard Eder
comments: Singer, musician and theater music composer.

name: The Swing Session
comments: San Francisco based six-piece swing band. The lead singer of this band, Peter "Pops" Walsh  performed with Seatrain and Pacific Gas & Electric, and played bass for Lou Reed in the Tots and the original version of the Rock & Roll Animal band.

name: Ruth Price [GB]
comments: Folksinger usually unaccompanied by instruments.

name: Sadie Greenwood
comments: Traditional singer who usually performs without instrumental accompaniment.

name: Rüdiger Piesker
comments: Orchestra leader and producer born in Berlin. He started his musical career in 1954 by assisting Werner Müller and his RIAS Tanzorchester before starting his own orchestra in 1962. He later also worked as producer for Polydor.

name: Betty Dempsey
comments: Country music singer, songwriter and guitarist. She was born in Baton Rouge, Louisiana and moved to New Jersey when she was 18.

name: Bedřich Smetana
comments: Composer who became closely identified with his country's aspirations to independent statehood, independent from the Austrian-Hungarian Empire. Internationally he is best known for his opera " Prodaná nevěsta " (The Bartered Bride) and for the symphonic cycle "Má vlast"("My Homeland"), which portrays the history, legends and landscape of the composer's native land.

name: Eduard Mörike
aliases: Generalmusikdirektor Eduard Mörike mit großem Symphonie-Orchester (Mitglieder der Staatskapelle, Berlin)
comments: Pianist, composer and Kapellmeister. He also was one of the house conductors of Parlophon of Berlin, itself part of the Carl Lindström A.G. group of companies in Germany.

name: Rebecca Wicking
comments: Musical theatre actress and singer.

name: Dick Scanlan

name: Česká filharmonie
comments: Symphony orchestra based in Prague. The orchestra's principal concert venue is the Rudolfinum on Jan Palach Square in the Old Town. The name "Czech Philharmonic Orchestra" appeared for the first time in 1894 as the title of the orchestra of the Prague National Theatre. It played its first concert under its current name on January 4, 1896 when Antonín Dvořák conducted his own compositions, but it did not become fully independent from the opera until 1901.
